Another possibility is that the building's elevator system has a limit on how many floors it can service, especially on rainy days, so stopping at the 10th floor might not be possible or safe. Or perhaps the elevator only goes up to a certain floor on rainy days due to maintenance or safety protocols.

I'm also thinking about the physical structure of the building. If the elevator shaft is designed to keep out water, maybe stopping at the 10th floor on a rainy day could cause water to pool or damage the elevator. Therefore, to prevent this, he takes the elevator all the way up, ensuring that the elevator stays dry and functional.

Additionally, maybe the man is trying to save time or avoid getting wet. If the 10th floor is near the ground floor, taking the elevator all the way up might be faster or more comfortable on a rainy evening, especially if he doesn't want to walk up the stairs in the rain.

But wait, the problem says he walks up five floors from the 10th to the 15th. So, perhaps on rainy days, the stairs are slippery, making it dangerous to walk up, so he takes the elevator instead. Alternatively, the elevator might be more reliable or faster on rainy days, making it a better choice.

I'm also considering the possibility that the elevator has a different starting point or that the building's design changes on rainy days, affecting the elevator's operation. Maybe the elevator is only available certain floors on rainy days, so he has to go all the way up to reach it.

Another angle could be that the man is trying to avoid paying for the elevator on rainy days, but that doesn't make much sense because he's still taking it. Alternatively, maybe the elevator fare is different on rainy days, but that's speculative.

I think the most plausible explanation is related to water entering the elevator shaft on rainy days. If the elevator stops at the 10th floor, water might enter the shaft, causing damage or flooding. Therefore, to prevent this, he takes the elevator all the way up to the 15th floor, ensuring that the elevator stays dry and functional.

So, putting it all together, the man takes the elevator all the way up to the 15th floor on rainy days to avoid water entering the elevator shaft, which would otherwise cause damage or create a hazard.
